Description: Amuletic figure probably carved from steatite, in the shape of a standing (?) Vervet monkey; smaller monkeys appearing on both shoulders, behind ears; green turquoise glaze remains, quite worn and dirty; hands and lower part broken off.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Dr David George Hogarth
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by Egyptian Museum, Cairo. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Vervet monkey's amulets supposedly help the wearer with love and sexual fulfilment during his life and in the underworld (Andrews 1994, 66-67). For other Vervet monkey's amulets from Naukratis: Oxford, Ashmolean Museum AN1896-1908-EA.875; Greenock, McLean Museum & Art Gallery 1987.454 (associated to a Bes); BM 1885,1101.49. On Vervet monkey's amulets: Andrews 1994, 66-67; Herrmann et al. 2010, 100-101 (type 52, especially no. 5-6). Andrews, C. 1994, Amulets of Ancient Egypt, London. Herrmann, C., Staubli, T., Berger-Lober, S., Keel, O., Schönbächler, G. 2010, 1001 Amulett : altägyptischer Zauber, monotheisierte Talismane, säkulare Magie, Bibel+Orient-Museum, Liebefeld, Stuttgart.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OK.264)
Condition: Rather fair, though incomplete and glaze damaged
